metadata.case_name: District and Sessions Judge v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant born on August 22, 1908, would normally retire on completing age of 55 years in August 1963.

On February 28, 1963, Government of Madhya Pradesh issued memorandum raising compulsory retirement age to 58 years for State Government servants, subject to exceptions, including power to retire after 55 years on three months' notice without assigning reasons, normally to weed out unsuitable employees. Effective from March 1, 1963. Amendments to State Civil Service Regulations to be issued.
In consequence of memorandum, appellant continued in service beyond August 1963.
On September 11, 1963, Government sent order to appellant retiring him with effect from afternoon of December 31, 1963, in pursuance of February 28, 1963 memorandum.

On November 29, 1963, Finance Department issued notification amending Fundamental Rules (FR) by deleting Chapter IX on compulsory retirement and inserting new FR 56 raising age to 58 years (60 for Class IV), effective from March 1, 1963. Published in Madhya Pradesh Gazette on December 6, 1963. Did not include power to retire after 55 on notice.
Appellant retired pursuant to September 11, 1963 order.
Appellant filed writ petition on March 24, 1964, challenging retirement order.
Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed writ petition on April 30, 1964 (Misc. Petition No. 132 of 1964), granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Appellant attained age of 58 years in August 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether the retirement order cast a stigma on the appellant amounting to removal requiring compliance with Article 311 of the Constitution.
Whether the memorandum dated February 28, 1963 amounts to a rule under Article 309 of the Constitution.
If memorandum not a rule, whether appellant could continue in service after August 1963 and take benefit of new FR 56 raising retirement age to 58 years.
Whether All India Services (Death-cum-Retirement Benefits) Rules, 1958 apply to the appellant as a District Judge.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule after amendment of November 29, 1963 (published December 6, 1963) contains no provision reserving power to retire after 55 years on three months' notice without reason; thus retirement on December 31, 1963 invalid.
Retirement order casts stigma amounting to removal, requiring action under Article 311.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 311; Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Order casts no stigma; no action under Article 311 necessary.
Memorandum of February 28, 1963 is itself a rule under Article 309; retirement valid under paragraph 5.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 309; Shyam Lal v. State of UP

respondent_arguments.text: If memorandum not a rule, appellant must be deemed retired in August 1963 under old rule of 55 years; cannot take advantage of new rule.
Appellant's case covered by All India Services (Death-cum-Retirement Benefits) Rules, 1958 as amended in 1963, validating retirement after 55 on notice.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: All India Services Rules 1958; MP Judicial Service Rules 1955 Rule 7(2)

court_reasoning.text: Order of retirement does not expressly contain words casting stigma; cannot infer stigma from memorandum's reference to weeding out unsuitable employees. Mere compulsory retirement before superannuation age without stigma words is not removal under Article 311.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No express stigma in order itself; cannot delve into files or extend memorandum's explanatory part.

court_reasoning.text: Memorandum of February 28, 1963 is not a rule under Article 309: not published in Gazette, in form of executive letter to Collectors promising future amendments, language conveys decision not rules. Contrast with actual FR 56 amendment on November 29, 1963 which omitted power to retire after 55.

Memorandum valid as general executive order under old FR 56 retaining services up to 58 years in public interest till proper rule framed; thus appellant continued after August 1963. New FR 56 applies post-publication, without power to retire after 55 on notice; retirement notice invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government could issue general retention order under old FR 56.

court_reasoning.text: All India Services Rules 1958 do not apply: MP Judicial Service Rules 1955 Rule 7(2) incorporates rules as on 1956 date of force, not future amendments like 1963.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No automatic inclusion of future amendments.

holdings.text: Compulsory retirement order without express stigma words does not amount to removal under Article 311.
February 28, 1963 memorandum is executive instruction, not rule under Article 309.
Appellant entitled to continue till 58 under old FR 56 via memorandum as general retention order; new FR 56 applies without early retirement power.
All India Services Rules 1958 not applicable to District Judges for post-1956 amendments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Order expressly casting stigma (undesirable to retain) amounts to removal under Art 311.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. M.M. Nagar
precedents_cited.relevance: Order with express stigma words in compulsory retirement is removal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Resolution published in Gazette announcing rules held as rule; unlike present unpublished memorandum.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art 309 for rule-making; Art 311 for removal safeguards. Memorandum not rule under 309.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules (Madhya Pradesh)
statutes_cited.relevance: Old FR 56 allowed retention post-55; amended Nov 29, 1963 to raise age to 58 effective Mar 1, 1963, omitting early retirement power.

statutes_cited.name: All India Services (Death-cum-Retirement Benefits) Rules, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Not applicable to District Judges via MP Judicial Service Rules for 1963 amendments.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Judicial Service (Classification, Recruitment and Conditions of Service) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Incorporates pension rules for IAS superior posts as on 1956, mutatis mutandis.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh New Pension Rules, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Do not apply to District Judges; early retirement provision added post-retirement date.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; retirement order quashed; appellant deemed to have continued in service; entitled to consequential benefits though attained 58 years in August 1966 precluding reinstatement.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of retirement order; consequential service benefits.

key_quotes.text: Where an order requiring a Government servant to retire compulsorily contains express words from which a stigma can be inferred, that order will amount to removal within the meaning of Art. 311.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies test for stigma in compulsory retirement orders.

key_quotes.text: The memorandum of February 28, 1963 contained merely executive instructions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects High Court's view that memo is rule under Art 309.

key_quotes.text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and quash the order of retirement passed in this case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final disposition in favor of appellant.
